description: On August 19th, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan urged people to refrain from prank calling the toll-free hotlines that are assisting the public with the national lockdown.
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 9th, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan stated that rumors circulating on social media about a second lockdown on September 11th are not true and urged citizens to refrain from "panic buying."
On September 29th, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan announced that the rumors of an imminent lockdown are false. They have requested for the public to stop spreading these rumors.
On October 4th, the Ministry of Health urged people to stop spreading rumors about a possible lockdown.
In Bhutan, as of 6 March, the government will close "schools and institutes" in three regions for two weeks.

description: On July 1st, some higher level schools were opened by the Bhutanese government, as a part of phase one reopening, under the following conditions. Classes X and XII will resume choosing their higher education specialization. Students of classes VII, VIII, IX, and XI will resume after phase one is completed. Classes VI and under will remain online. Technical and vocational education training will start in-person on July 1st. The Royal University of Bhutan will have final year students on campus, while first and second year students are online.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description: On March 6, 2020, the Bhutanese government imposes "two weeks restriction on all incoming tourists".
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 23, the Bhutanese Government announced closure of all international land borders.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On September 7th, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan announced that the requirements for those entering Bhutan would be as followed: foreigners must produce a negative COVID-19 test that had been taken within 72 hours of returning, and all Bhutanese citizens and foreigners must undergo a 21 day quarantine. Migrant workers from India may produce a RAPID ANTIGEN negative test certificate.
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
On October 7th, the Ministry of Health in Bhutan announced that individuals who were traveling out of the country would have to adhere to three steps. 
1. Visit a flu clinic to get a COVID test and medical examination.
2. Collect the negative result and "fit to fly" certificate.
3. Have a hard copy of the certificate while leaving the country.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Beginning on April 14th, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan is requiring persons with disabilities to register with their district (dzongkhag).

On April 28, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan announced the mandatory use of the "Druk Trace app," which is used for contact tracing by the MoH. This app will utilize QR codes on public transportation and businesses through individuals scanning these codes when they pass through the area.
On March 9, 2020, the Bhutanese government established new walk-in clinics for those with respiratory symptoms.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 14, 2020, the Bhutanese government established a laboratory facility within a hospital for testing.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 24, 2020, the Bhutanese government called back all doctors undergoing specialization abroad for virus readiness.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 24, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan gave the Ministry of Education 900 thermometers in an effort to assist the preparation of schools.
On April 3, 2020, the Bhutanese government decided to test incomers from high-risk countries at the main airport regardless of whether or not they presented symptoms.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 17th, the Ministry of Health urged citizens in Thimpu who had traveled to or from, since August 1st, Phuntsholing to get tested. Later, the Bhutanese government stated that the last day for getting yourself tested if you had traveled to or from Phuntsholing would be on August 25th.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On August 26th, the Ability Bhutan Society got approval to distribute special movement cards to those with disabilities or single parents living with children.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 28th, the head of the Lhuentse dzongkhag announced that the town of Phaling, town of Autsho, and the Khoma gewog would be split into three zones. Movement cards would be distributed within each to determine where citizens can go and when, along with restricting movement within borders.

On August 11th, the Prime Minister's Office of Bhutan announced a national lockdown following the positive test of a women that visited the capital city. The government will enforce restrictions within and between all districts. All offices, commercial establishments, schools and institutions will be closed. The government will prosecute violations of the lockdown under Section 410 of the Penal Code.

On July 15th, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan announced that they would implement the the COVID-19 Emergency Response and Health Systems Preparedness Project financed by the World Bank. This project will strengthen surveillance and contact tracing, along with identifying the assessments that will be needed to carried out under the project.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On October 5th, the Prime Minster's Office of Bhutan announced the beginning of the National Credit Guarantee Scheme (NCGS), which will aim to help ease economic hardship throughout Bhutan by making it easier to access credit.
type_text: The NCGS is a credit program to with the goal of helping individual citizens of Bhutan and helping the country in the following: a) Boosting exports; b) Reducing economic dependency by investing in import substitution-based projects; c) Promoting innovation and technology; and d) Creating jobs to absorb the displaced and unemployed.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 31st, the Bhutanese Ministry of Health announced that measures would be put in place in order to prevent health facilities from being compromised. These measures include one attendant per patient, no visitors and no outside food, and testing for COVID upon admission to the facility.

description: On Friday September 11th, the Prime Minister's Office of Bhutan announced that the Centenary Farmers’ Market in Thimphu will remain closed due to a breakdown in social distancing and rule following. The government hopes to open the CFM within the month at a multi-level car park.

description: On March 6, 2020, the Bhutanese government deferred all mass gatherings until further notice.
On March 6, 2020, the Bhutanese government deferred all mass gatherings until further notice.
On March 27, 2020, the Bhutanese government urged individuals keep physical distance at public places like grocery outlets, vegetable markets, fuel depots, banks and hospitals.
On March 29, 2020, the Bhutanese government decided to halve the carrying capacity of buses and taxis for physical distancing.
